segment.target: Template settings classes

segment.source: Template settings classes
segment.target: Template settings classes

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: We assume that you can add controls to your UI, set their properties, and attach event handlers.
segment.target: We assume that you can add controls to your UI, set their properties, and attach event handlers.

segment.source: For instructions for adding controls to your app, see Add controls and handle events.
segment.target: For instructions for adding controls to your app, see Add controls and handle events.

segment.source: We also assume that you know the basics of how to define a custom template for a control by making a copy of the default template and editing it.
segment.target: We also assume that you know the basics of how to define a custom template for a control by making a copy of the default template and editing it.

segment.source: For more info on this, see Quickstart: Control templates.
segment.target: For more info on this, see Quickstart: Control templates.

segment.source: The scenario for TemplateSettings classes
segment.target: The scenario for TemplateSettings classes

segment.source: TemplateSettings classes provide a set of properties that are used when you define a new control template for a control.
segment.target: TemplateSettings classes provide a set of properties that are used when you define a new control template for a control.

segment.source: The properties have values such as pixel measurements for the size of certain UI element parts.
segment.target: The properties have values such as pixel measurements for the size of certain UI element parts.

segment.source: The values are sometimes calculated values that come from control logic that isn't typically easy to override or even access.
segment.target: The values are sometimes calculated values that come from control logic that isn't typically easy to override or even access.

segment.source: Some of the properties are intended as From and To values that control transitions and animations of parts, and thus the relevant TemplateSettings properties come in pairs.
segment.target: Some of the properties are intended as From and To values that control transitions and animations of parts, and thus the relevant TemplateSettings properties come in pairs.

segment.source: There are several TemplateSettings classes.
segment.target: There are several TemplateSettings classes.

segment.source: All of them are in the Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives namespace.
segment.target: All of them are in the Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives namespace.

segment.source: Here's a list of the classes, and a link to the TemplateSettings property of the relevant control.
segment.target: Here's a list of the classes, and a link to the TemplateSettings property of the relevant control.

segment.source: This TemplateSettings property is how you access the TemplateSettings values for the control, and can establish template bindings to its properties:
segment.target: This TemplateSettings property is how you access the TemplateSettings values for the control, and can establish template bindings to its properties:

segment.source: ComboBoxTemplateSettings: value of ComboBox.TemplateSettings
segment.target: ComboBoxTemplateSettings: value of ComboBox.TemplateSettings

segment.source: GridViewItemTemplateSettings: value of GridViewItem.TemplateSettings
segment.target: GridViewItemTemplateSettings: value of GridViewItem.TemplateSettings

segment.source: ListViewItemTemplateSettings: value of ListViewItem.TemplateSettings
segment.target: ListViewItemTemplateSettings: value of ListViewItem.TemplateSettings

segment.source: ProgressBarTemplateSettings: value of ProgressBar.TemplateSettings
segment.target: ProgressBarTemplateSettings: value of ProgressBar.TemplateSettings

segment.source: ProgressRingTemplateSettings: value of ProgressRing.TemplateSettings
segment.target: ProgressRingTemplateSettings: value of ProgressRing.TemplateSettings

segment.source: SettingsFlyoutTemplateSettings: value of SettingsFlyout.TemplateSettings
segment.target: SettingsFlyoutTemplateSettings: value of SettingsFlyout.TemplateSettings

segment.source: ToggleSwitchTemplateSettings: value of ToggleSwitch.TemplateSettings
segment.target: ToggleSwitchTemplateSettings: value of ToggleSwitch.TemplateSettings

segment.source: ToolTipTemplateSettings: value of ToolTip.TemplateSettings
segment.target: ToolTipTemplateSettings: value of ToolTip.TemplateSettings

segment.source: TemplateSettings properties are always intended to be used in XAML, not code.
segment.target: TemplateSettings properties are always intended to be used in XAML, not code.

segment.source: They are read-only sub-properties of a read-only TemplateSettings property of a parent control.
segment.target: They are read-only sub-properties of a read-only TemplateSettings property of a parent control.

segment.source: For an advanced custom control scenario, where you're creating a new Control-based class and thus can influence the control logic, consider defining a custom TemplateSettings property on the control in order to communicate info that might be useful for anyone that is re-templating the control.
segment.target: For an advanced custom control scenario, where you're creating a new Control-based class and thus can influence the control logic, consider defining a custom TemplateSettings property on the control in order to communicate info that might be useful for anyone that is re-templating the control.

segment.source: As that property's read-only value, define a new TemplateSettings class related to your control that has read-only properties for each of the info items that are relevant for template measurements, animation positioning, and so on, and give callers the runtime instance of that class that's initialized using your control logic.
segment.target: As that property's read-only value, define a new TemplateSettings class related to your control that has read-only properties for each of the info items that are relevant for template measurements, animation positioning, and so on, and give callers the runtime instance of that class that's initialized using your control logic.

segment.source: TemplateSettings classes are derived from DependencyObject, so that the properties can use the dependency property system for property-changed callbacks.
segment.target: TemplateSettings classes are derived from DependencyObject, so that the properties can use the dependency property system for property-changed callbacks.

segment.source: But the dependency property identifiers for the properties aren't exposed as public API, because the TemplateSettings properties are meant to be read-only to callers.
segment.target: But the dependency property identifiers for the properties aren't exposed as public API, because the TemplateSettings properties are meant to be read-only to callers.

segment.source: How to use TemplateSettings in a control template
segment.target: How to use TemplateSettings in a control template

segment.source: Here's an example that comes from the starting default XAML control templates.
segment.target: Here's an example that comes from the starting default XAML control templates.

segment.source: This particular one is from the default template of ProgressRing:
segment.target: This particular one is from the default template of ProgressRing:

segment.source: The full XAML for the ProgressRing template is hundreds of lines, so this is just a tiny excerpt.
segment.target: The full XAML for the ProgressRing template is hundreds of lines, so this is just a tiny excerpt.

segment.source: This XAML defines a control part that is one of 6 Ellipse elements that portray the spinning animation for indeterminate progress.
segment.target: This XAML defines a control part that is one of 6 Ellipse elements that portray the spinning animation for indeterminate progress.

segment.source: As a developer, you might not like the circles and might use a different graphics primitive or a different basic shape for how the animation progresses.
segment.target: As a developer, you might not like the circles and might use a different graphics primitive or a different basic shape for how the animation progresses.

segment.source: For example, you might compose a ProgressRing that uses a set of Rectangle elements arranged in a square instead.
segment.target: For example, you might compose a ProgressRing that uses a set of Rectangle elements arranged in a square instead.

segment.source: If so, each individual Rectangle component of your new template might look like this:
segment.target: If so, each individual Rectangle component of your new template might look like this:

segment.source: The reason that the TemplateSettings properties are useful here is because they are calculated values coming from the basic control logic of ProgressRing.
segment.target: The reason that the TemplateSettings properties are useful here is because they are calculated values coming from the basic control logic of ProgressRing.

segment.source: The calculation is dividing up the overall ActualWidth and ActualHeight of the ProgressRing, and allotting a calculated measurement for each of the motion elements in its templates so that the template parts can size to content.
segment.target: The calculation is dividing up the overall ActualWidth and ActualHeight of the ProgressRing, and allotting a calculated measurement for each of the motion elements in its templates so that the template parts can size to content.

segment.source: Here's another example usage from the default XAML control templates, this time showing one of the property sets that are the From and To of an animation.
segment.target: Here's another example usage from the default XAML control templates, this time showing one of the property sets that are the From and To of an animation.

segment.source: This is from the ComboBox default template:
segment.target: This is from the ComboBox default template:

segment.source: Again there is lots of XAML in the template so we only show an excerpt.
segment.target: Again there is lots of XAML in the template so we only show an excerpt.

segment.source: And this is only one of several states and theme animations that each use the same ComboBoxTemplateSettings properties.
segment.target: And this is only one of several states and theme animations that each use the same ComboBoxTemplateSettings properties.

segment.source: For ComboBox, use of the ComboBoxTemplateSettings values through bindings enforces that related animations in the template will stop and start at positions that are based on shared values, and thus transition smoothly.
segment.target: For ComboBox, use of the ComboBoxTemplateSettings values through bindings enforces that related animations in the template will stop and start at positions that are based on shared values, and thus transition smoothly.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: When you do use TemplateSettings values as part of your control template, make sure you're setting properties that match the type of the value.
segment.target: When you do use TemplateSettings values as part of your control template, make sure you're setting properties that match the type of the value.

segment.source: If not, you might need to create a value converter for the binding so that the target type of the binding can be converted from a different source type of the TemplateSettings value.
segment.target: If not, you might need to create a value converter for the binding so that the target type of the binding can be converted from a different source type of the TemplateSettings value.

segment.source: For more info, see IValueConverter.
segment.target: For more info, see IValueConverter.
